pulls.title: First take on proxy auth hint
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
Here is my first stab at authentication hints.

Key use case is to allow client proxy selection based on supported authentication methods.

For example, enterprise environment could have an IoT device that is only capable of TLS PSK, a workload that would like to do non-interactive mTLS authentication and an end user device that is happy to do an interactive authentication flow using HTTP methods. All these endpoints could obtain the same information about available proxies and select a proxy that is best suited to their capabilities and preferences.

comments.author: yaroslavros
comments.body: Closing based on WG consensus.

```suggestion
`http-schemes` MUST NOT be provided if authentication method is not set to `http-proxy`.
```

pulls.title: Added mandatory key
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
This makes format extensible in the future and allows proprietary extensions.
On top of that it addresses the question of what clients should do if they cannot fully process proxy destination restrictions. If corresponding key is in `mandatory` list, they must ignore the proxy, otherwise they may proceed even without full processing of the destination restriction list.

```suggestion
Multiple proxy dictionaries can contain the same `identifier` value. In this case, the client
```

```suggestion
can choose any of the proxies; however, the client ought to prefer using the same proxy for the consecutive requests
```

```suggestion
to the same proxy `identifier` to increase connection reuse.
```

```suggestion
all other hosts within "internal.example.org". The client will use the same proxy for the following
```

pulls.title: Added more specific references to RFC 8801
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body: To address first part of https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/int-area/O-S89f6JVdEPrCLF7VMJYdarvsc/

pulls.title: Added reference to expiry and randomized backoff
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body: Based on feedback from Watson Ladd.

pulls.title: Changed hostname to host with reference to RFC 3986
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
To address feedback from Philip Lisiecki

> When the proxy field is hostname:port, can an IP address be used? For IPv6, should the address use [ipv6]:port like with a URI or just IPv6:port? I didn't see IPv6 mentioned in the referenced HTTP spec section, although maybe it's actually transitively specified. Regardless, is it worth calling out explicitly whether or not IP addresses are OK and if so whether the [] is required here?

pulls.title: Clarified limited use of proxies with the identifier
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
Addresses feedback from Philip Lisiecki:

>> The value of identifier key is a string that can be used to refer to a particular proxy from other dictionaries, specifically those defined in Section 4.

> It is unclear whether an entry with an identifier is allowed to be used even if there is no relevant proxy-match. E.g., is the intent something like "Proxies with an identifier key SHOULD only be used when a proxy-match applies"? Or is it meant to be more vague in some way?

pulls.title: Removed confusing "Comma-separated list"
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
Addresses following feedback from Philip Lisiecki:

>> Comma-separated port list may contain individual port numbers...

> The explicit mention of "comma" makes me think that ["80,443,12345"] might be supported in addition to a standard JSON list ["80","443","12345"].

pulls.title: Clarified destination rules match criteria
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
To address feedback from Philip Lisiecki:

>> Multiple rules can match for the same destination, in which case all are considered to be accessible through the matching proxies in case the sets of proxies are different.

> I'm confused. This seems to suggest that the client can/should continue looking for more matches after making a match, but that conflicts with the "first match" rule proposed just before. Are there some cases where clients can/should continue looking for rule matches? If so, when is that OK to do? Is this just a matter of preference levels, except for empty proxy sets, which always mean "stop here"?
> On a related note, what if I have a proxy-match none of whose proxy identifiers apply to the protocol, e.g., a TCP connection but the identified proxy only has "connect-udp"? Should the client consider that "not a match" and continue looking for more rules? Or stop and declare no proxy available?

comments.body: I think this is reasonable.

pulls.title: Corrected typos
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
Address feedback from Philip Lisiecki:

>> traffic that matches the rule needs to match at one of the entries in

> Typo? => "at least one of"

>> In this case, the client would not send to the proxies any TCP traffic that is not destined to hosts matching "*.[intranet.example.org](http://intranet.example.org/)", [192.168.0.0/16](http://192.168.0.0/16) or 2001:DB8::/32.

> Typo? => Either "that is destined" or "the client would only send" (The stated logic appears to be backwards.)

comments.body:
This sentence is a bit hard to read for me. Maybe we can write something like: 
"In this case, the client will not forward TCP traffic
that is destined to hosts matching "\*.intranet.example.org", 192.168.0.0/16 or 2001:DB8::/32, through the proxies."

I like your version!
Updated text accordingly.

pulls.title: Clarified example 1
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
Addresses following feedback from Philip Lisiecki:

> Example #1: Would it be helpful to add a note that domains outside of *.[internal.example.com](http://internal.example.com/) would not use these proxies at all? I see that's explicitly covered in example #2, so that may be sufficient...

pulls.title: Clarify that client DNS search suffix is not relevant
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body:
This addresses following feedback from Philip Lisiecki:

> proxy-match.domains: The examples lack trailing ".".  Are these to be interpreted using the client's default DNS suffixes or be treated as absolute domain names regardless?

comments.body:
```suggestion
at the end of a domain name is not required; the matching logic is the same regardless of its presence or absence.
```
I wonder if the URI reference is correct here — the traffic being matched wouldn't necessarily have a URI as its input. Can we just remove this sentence perhaps?

pulls.title: GeoIP: Add OHTTP use case to motivation
pulls.author: DavidSchinazi
pulls.body: This PR adds the OHTTP use case to the geoIP draft, and mentions that this is intended for specific use cases and not general browsing. It also removes some of the early text on client hint since that's not the focus of the background/motivation.

comments.body:
Maybe spell this as:
```suggestion
intermediaries that hide client IP addresses, such as Oblivious HTTP (OHTTP) relays.
```
And add a reference?
